I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
A.  Analysis of Key Issues 
1.  Financial inclusion continues to be on the world’s development goals agenda with an 
estimated 1.7 billion people globally still without an account either with a financial institution or 
through a mobile money provider.1 Most of these are from developing economies, such as 
Bangladesh, India, Indonesia and Pakistan. While progress has been made in reducing the 
unbanked population number, there is a persistent gender gap in women’s access to even basic 
accounts in the financial system, with 56% remaining unbanked (footnote 1). Increased access to 
financial services and products requires a more gender inclusive financial system that addresses 
the specific demand- and supply-side barriers women and women’s businesses face. 2 
 
2.  Many financial institutions (FIs) in developing economies often do not have a specific focus 
or understanding of the market challenges and potential for underserved customer segments, 
such as women borrowers.3 Moreover, incentives to reach this target group are often absent. 
Therefore, many FIs do not actively target women and women’s businesses and consequently, 
affordable products and services remain out of reach in ADB’s developing member countries 
(DMCs).  
 
3.  The emergence and spread of the corona virus disease (COVID-19) will exacerbate 
barriers to finance for women borrowers. Emerging evidence suggests that in lower- and low-
income countries, lost income will result in an increase in relative poverty for informal workers and 
their families and that compared to men’s lives, women’s economic and productive lives are 
disproportionately and differently affected.4 The hardest hit sectors include retail trade and service 
industries such as street vending and domestic work-typically low-wage jobs that rely on in-person 
connections and often carried out by women.5 Small women’s businesses have lost their incomes 
and often do not have necessary cash reserves to survive for a longer period or face barriers to 
access finance to adapt their business models to the “new normal” environment. A survey on the 
impact of COVID-19 on women’s businesses in Papua New Guinea (PNG) has for example found 
that 40.9% of smaller or semi-formal businesses have reported a temporary halt in operations. 6 
 
4.  COVID-19 has also reinforced the crucial importance of a digital economy, i.e. to change 
business models into digital business models and to integrate digital channels into how financial 
service providers or businesses engage with customers. It is expected that by 2025, digital 
financial services will give the world a $3.7 trillion (or 6%) GDP boost, creating 95 million new 
jobs, $2.1 trillion in new credit, and $4.2 trillion in new deposits.7 Albeit the study is from 2016, the 
findings are still relevant and COVID-19 is expected to accelerate the efforts for the digital 
transformation. 8 
 
 
1  World Bank, Global Findex 2017. 
2  Women’s businesses can comprise micro- small and medium women-owned or women-managed businesses and 
in line with respective country definitions, if available. 
3  Financial institutions in this context are banks and non-bank financial institutions including microfinance institutions, 
housing finance, and insurance companies, for instance. 
4  UN Women 2020, Policy Brief: The Impact of COVID-19 on Women, 9 April 2020. 
5  Women in Informal Employment: Globalizing and Organizing (WIEGO), #3 Social Protection Responses to Covid-
19, 2020. 
6  CIBE 2020. COVID-19’s Arrival in PNG: Impacts on women-owned and -operated MSMEs. July 2020. Port Moresby 
7  McKinsey Global Institute, DIGITAL FINANCE FOR ALL: POWERING INCLUSIVE GROWTH IN EMERGING 
ECONOMIES, September 2016. 
8  PWC 2020. COVID-19 A digital technology agenda driving an accelerated transition to the new normal. June 2020

2 
5.  ADB’s nonsovereign operations have supported financial inclusion of women through its 
various instruments and programs with a good track record. This includes credit lines to FIs 
onlending to individual women borrowers and/or women entrepreneurs. ADB has also provided 
equity  to  support  FIs  that  are  financing  women,  such  as  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs). 
Technical assistance has been used to develop products for women borrowers, expand financial 
literacy training, fund marketing campaigns geared at potential women borrowers, and create and 
enhance digital finance solutions that will better serve women borrowers, for instance. Such 
transactions have defined gender targets that support women’s access to finance with additional 
features in certain transactions supporting geographic regions where women are particularly 
underserved. Through ADB’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program, ADB 
provides guarantees to partner FIs’ local currency loans to MFIs, which expands access to finance 
for the lower-income populations in DMCs, mostly in rural areas and women. As of end September 
2020, ADB has facilitated over $1.36 billion in financing through the program, reaching 7 million 
borrowers of whom 98% are women.  
 
6.  The  proposed technical  assistance  builds  on and  expands  ADB’s  gender  initiatives 
through FIs. The TA will fund the development of an online platform, which is expected to increase 
gender-responsive financing and provide innovative digital solutions to address the changing 
business environment. To help reduce barriers for women and women’s businesses to access 
finance concerted efforts in dissemination of best practices and results and continued support to 
partner FIs and women’s businesses is necessary.9 The “Women’s Financing Marketplace” (or 
the Marketplace) is also expected to create more visibility on partnerships, such as with the 
Women’s Entrepreneur Finance Initiative (We-Fi) which supports ADB’s innovative activities for 
improving access to finance to women businesses in Papua New Guinea and Viet Nam and also 
finances specific activities under the TA.  
 
7.  As mentioned, the need for a digital ecosystem has become even more crucial with the 
COVID-19 pandemic. The Marketplace will, therefore, be innovative in its work and take a digital 
approach for interaction and engagement as it will, among others, engage also through social 
media channels to build a subscriber and follower list and facilitate the engagement of an online 
community through linkages and resources on content relevant for the FIs and their female 
borrowers.10  
 
8.   As  a  starting  point,  the  platform  will  have  various  case  studies  or  other  type  of 
communications aggregating in one location the work that has been done through ADB for FIs 
onlending to women, including through TAs. The Marketplace will further; (i) provide support and 
capacity building to FIs through digital toolkits, webinars and online support; and (ii) support 
identification and development of cutting-edge technologies, such as for example alternative 
gender-responsive credit scoring models11, through crowd sourcing technologies and digital 
sandbox programs, which will be piloted in one or two countries first (Papua New Guinea has 
been identified as the first).  
 
B.  Justification for Cluster Modality 
 
9.  As the Women’s Financing Marketplace is a new initiative, there are no funds attached to 
it which would provide for the initial IT infrastructure set-up and maintenance of the site. A 
separate transaction technical assistance cluster (TA) is proposed. The TA adopts a cluster 
 
9  Barriers are for example limited financial literacy, insufficient credit history, lack of collateral. 
10  For example, content on women’s businesses and sustainability/green lending. 
11  A gender-responsive credit scoring model would consider also women specific data or behavior for the algorithms.

3 
modality for four reasons: (i) it provides an opportunity to develop the Marketplace on a small 
scale and expand gradually without tying down the entire projected TA resource requirements at 
the outset; (ii) it allows the TA to be more flexible and responsive to the needs of FIs and women’s 
businesses by adding features, tools, and linkages; (iii) it facilitates a “One ADB” approach by 
working with other departments or available funding sources for development of support products 
without having to use the TA resources, and (iv) it is more efficient than processing individual 
standalone TAs each year. Staff engaged in the Marketplace will, for example, work with ADB’s 
Information  Technology  Department  (ITD)  for  innovation  challenges  and  digital  sandbox 
programs to identify digital solutions to improve FIs’ financial service delivery channels.12 Related 
to this, funds from the WAVES program will be used for activities in the Pacific.13 
 
10.  The proposed TA is designed to support (i) the design, set-up, and maintenance of the 
Marketplace; (ii) aggregation and dissemination of products, results, best practice examples on 
gender financing within ADB and to a broader audience; (iii) support for the implementation of 
hackathons and digital sandboxes together with ITD on innovations for digital financial service 
delivery; (iv) capacity building for FIs to improve their gender-responsive financing efforts, and 
women’s businesses to sustainably grow their businesses, as needed; (v) linkages to other 
programs and initiatives on enabling access to finance for women, internal and external to ADB14; 
and (vi) fostering a community platform.. Further details on the subprojects are provided in Annex 
2. The TA will be regional in nature as it will support FIs, as well as women’s businesses in all of 
ADB’s DMCs. The TA will have various subprojects. After completion of subproject 1, a review 
will take place before the Marketplace will be expanded with additional features according to the 
feedback from FIs and other partners.15 
 
11.  The TA is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities including (i) addressing 
remaining poverties and reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality; and 
(iii) promoting rural development and food security.16 The expansion of access to finance for low 
income women supports ADB’s Operational Plan for Priority 2 on Gender Equality.17 Inclusive 
finance is also one of the three pillars of ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan which was re-
affirmed in its 2016 review.18  
 
C.  Outcome and Outputs 
12.  Overall outcome. The TA will have the following overall outcome: sustainable financial 
inclusion for women and women’s businesses increased. Through a combination of different 
support mechanisms and digital tools for financial institutions19, women and women’s businesses 
will receive more financing to sustainably grow their business and become more resilient. TA 
subprojects will generally deliver all or some of the following outputs, as to be specified by each 
transaction TA subproject proposal. 
 
13.  Output 1: Finalized design, set-up, and maintenance of the Women’s Financing 
Marketplace (Subprojects 1 and 4). The TA will support design of the Marketplace. This will

include: (i) conducting a mapping exercise of existing gender finance initiatives, (ii) a design sprint 
exercise and a survey to finalize the design of the marketplace (target audience, features, 
distribution channels, user friendliness, linkages, pilot), (iii) enhancing partnerships with the public 
and private sector and facilitating linkages through the Marketplace to leverage other initiatives; 
(iv)  aggregating  and  disseminating  gender-responsive  financing  products,  results  and  best 
practice examples; and (v) contracting resources to establish and maintain the IT infrastructure 
and social media accounts as well as the content.  
 
14.  Output 2: Innovative technologies designed to support digital gender-responsive 
ecosystems (Subproject 2). The TA will e.g. support FIs (footnote 3) in the identification and 
development of cutting-edge technology solutions for digital, gender- responsive financial service 
delivery in a safe environment with a potential to commercially pilot such solutions. The support 
will, among others, be carried out with ITD using crowd sourcing technology or digital sandboxes 
(footnote 12).  
 
15.  Output  3:  Capacity  building  to  financial  institutions  and  women’s  businesses 
conducted (Subproject 3). The TA will support capacity building of FIs (on areas to be defined) 
and women’s businesses on improving the viability of their businesses.  
 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
16.  The TA is expected not to exceed $2,500,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by 
multiple donors, including but not limited to ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF), 
We-Fi, and other donors’ contributions. Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will 
be presented in each TA subproject proposal submitted for approval. ADB will seek cost-matching 
from its client as much as possible. 
 
17.  The first subproject is estimated to cost $600,000 and financing of subsequent subprojects 
is subject to availability of TA funds or other co-financing sources. The funds will cover website 
development, IT infrastructure (as necessary), one or two commercial pilots, preparation of 
training  and  capacity  building  materials,  remuneration,  travel,  and  per  diem  for 
international/national  consultants;  conference-related  or  seminar  expenditures;  and 
miscellaneous expenses.20  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will administer the TA and its Private Sector Operations Department’s, Financial 
Institutions Division will implement the cluster TA and each subproject. Disbursement under the 
cluster TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2020,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  TA  will  be  implemented  from  
January 2021– December 2024. Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for approval to 
Director General, PSOD, in accordance with the business process for transaction TA cluster 
processing. Subproject activities will start only after approval.

20.  Consulting services. Individual consultants (national/international) will be recruited by 
PSOD/PSFI in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and the associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. A firm may 
also be recruited using the quality-and-cost based selection method or shopping procedures. A 
single-source selection may also be considered, subject to required approvals, should specific 
expertise be required. The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative; and 
estimates will be finalized prior to approval of each TA subproject. 
 
21.  Social media and websites. The TA will initially use ADB-supported website and social 
media channels that are maintained by DOC, and follow the ADB Guidelines on Social Media and 
the Branding Tool Kit.21 During the review other options might be considered, depending on the

by ADB will automatically be deactivated by DOC and/or ITD.  
 
22.  Co-financier requirements. The TA will consist of subprojects financed by either ADB 
and/or  donor  funding.  Each  TA  subproject  financed  by  donor  funding  will  be  designed  in 
accordance  with  the  trust  fund’s  requirements.  Eligibility,  implementation,  monitoring  and 
reporting provisions will be specified in the TA subproject proposals.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Technical Assistance for the Women’s Financing Marketplace and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
